intro: Hippocrepis glandulosa, commonly known as the glandular bellflower, is a flowering plant belonging to the family Brassicaceae. It is characterized by its hairy, glandular leaves and showy, bell-shaped flowers that typically range in color from white to pale purple. Native to Europe and parts of Asia, it thrives in rocky or sandy soils and is often found in alpine or coastal habitats. The plant produces small, capsule-like fruits that contain numerous seeds, which are dispersed by wind. Its structure and growth habits make it an important component of its native ecosystems.
